headline: Ruben Amorim press conference LIVE - Man United injury updates and early team news vs Everton
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim has spoken to the media ahead of the clash with Everton on Monday night.

Amorim addressed the injuries around Benjamin Sesko, Harry Maguire and Kobbie Mainoo. Sesko and Maguire are not expected to feature against Everton but Mainoo could return to training on Saturday ahead of the fixture.

The United head coach was also quizzed on when his players who are heading to the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) will be leaving the camp. Amad, Bryan Mbeumo and Noussair Mazraoui could all be joining up with their national teams next month.

Meanwhile, Amorim was asked to reflect on the changes he has witnessed over his first year in charge of the Reds. Monday will mark a year to the day since he stepped into the dugout for the first time in the 1-1 draw at Ipswich Town.
Take a look at everything Amorim had to say in his press conference below.
That is all from the Amorim press conference. His full quotes from part one are below.

It was everything going really fast. The first thinking was the environment was different in the Premier League and I was excited with that. Right away I knew that we would struggle with some things but there was a feeling that yes, it was the best league and best club in the world. But at the same time it was a big job and it is going to take a lot of work.

We are showing that [improvements] but the important thing is that it doesn't matter what we did in the recent games we cannot forget that we still started in that point and suffered a lot last year and we have to take that into account. We have to play every game like it is the last one or the first one. But if you ask me, I expect a team with more control and more dominance, playing better football and the most important thing that we are more competitive in every way.

He can play left wing-back but of course the load that a player does in that position is a little different if you are doing that on a daily basis. He is more prepared to do that position but of course he can play there, he is a smart player and he is fit in the moment so I think he is an option.

A smart intelligent football player can play in a lot of positions but it is not the right position for him. He needs more time to work there and he is not working there but in an emergency he can play, but I am not thinking about that. I feel Licha is becoming close to being able to play. We need to be careful, he is going to struggle in the first minutes but he is clearly in a better position than he was two weeks ago.

In our league, the table doesn't matter because everything is so tight that it is irrelevant. If you know the history of our team you never know when it is a difficult game. So that [run of fixtures] is completely irrelevant in the Premier League.

It is a concern but we already knew. There is an opportunity for other players. We have also the under-21s. We need to send a message in that time so we will see. But of course it is not ideal because they are so important in our team and we don't have a long squad but again, our academy is for these moments and they will be ready.

We have rules when we have to release players, we will see. We are doing our job trying to maintain the players a little longer but it is not in our hands but we will try to do everything to protect the club, protect the players and protect the national team.
I think they will leave two weeks before the start so we will try to get something with the federations but we will need to respect their wills in this case.
Maguire is not ready, Kobbie didn't train today but I think tomorrow we could see Kobbie so we will see.

He is going to stay a few weeks out. I don't know how long but it is not that serious we have to be careful with him. He is going to recover. He is doing the recovery and he is feeling better so we expect in a few weeks to have him back.
I think it is going to be more or less he will be back at the same time as Amad and Mbeumo leave for AFCON. I don't want to say for sure but when they are going to the camp I expect to have Ben back.
Amorim is with us and the press conference is about to begin
We are still waiting for the start of the press conference, stay tuned for further updates...

Martinez looked comfortable during that training session earlier and it is expected he could play some role in the matchday squad on Monday. The big question is how easy he will find it to get back into the starting XI. Shaw has played excellently this season and while the Argentine will be eased back into regular football, there is no guarantee that he will eventually take the Englishman's spot.
Amorim's press conference will be starting in just a few minutes...

During the training session this morning, we have already mentioned that Sesko did not look to be involved with the rest of the squad. Two other absentees were Maguire and Mainoo. The centre-back came off injured against Spurs before the international break while Mainoo did not travel to north London due to a knock. We expect to hear why those two were not involved shortly...

There is likely to be a slight delay to Amorim's press conference this afternoon. We should be hearing from the manager at shortly after the previously scheduled 1.30pm start. Stay tuned as we continue the build-up to the press conference.
We are just half an hour away from Amorim's first press conference since the international break. Let us know what questions you hope he will address this afternoon in the comments section!
A reminder that we will be hearing from Amorim this afternoon at 1.30pm. Ahead of then, here are the topics we expect to be covered during the press conference:

United have just taken part in an open training session at Carrington and there appeared to be no Sesko with the first-team squad. Amorim will be providing an update on his fitness this afternoon at the press conference.
Read more here>>>

To mark his first year in charge of United, Amorim sat down with the Premier League to reflect on the past 12 months. During the interview, he addressed the prospect of selling players to avoid potential PSR issues. And the Portuguese head coach hinted that academy players could be the ones leaving the club.
Read more here>>>

We are expecting to receive an update on the fitness of Sesko during Amorim's press conference later. The Slovenian suffered a knee injury in the draw at Spurs and could not continue, leaving the Reds down to ten men for the final moments of the fixture. The centre-forward did not join up with his national team during the international break and there has been reports he could be out for a month. We understand that timeline is currently speculative but Amorim should shed more light on the matter today.

United have confirmed they will officially open one of the largest safe standing sections in the Premier League when Everton make the trip to Old Trafford on Monday night. United installed 6,000 additional rail seats in the second tier of the Stretford End in September. The work has now been completed and certified by the Sports Grounds Safety Authority for safe standing.
Read more here>>>
Amorim is set to address the media at 1.30pm this afternoon. We shall provide you with everything the United boss has to say as soon as we hear it.

Hello and welcome to our live press conference blog. Amorim will be addressing the media this afternoon from Carrington for the first time since the draw at Tottenham earlier this month. That game continued the Reds' unbeaten run and left United just a point outside the top four. The focus will be on injuries ahead of the game with question marks surrounding the fitness of Sesko.
Stay tuned for updates from Carrington right here.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Marcus Rashford blow, Semenyo release clause, Elliot Anderson battle
body: Hello and welcome to our Manchester United transfer news live blog.

With the January transfer window fast approaching, United are at the centre of several rumours. Antoine Semenyo is currently the trending name ahead of the winter trading period with several Premier League teams keen to sign him from Bournemouth.
United are reported to be part of that race, with the Cherries' front-man impressing so far this season. But he's not the only forward to be linked with a move to Old Trafford.

Karim Adeyemi of Borussia Dortmund is a different attacker to be linked with an Old Trafford switch. There are also some reports of United showing an interest in teammate Serhou Guirassy, raising the possibility of a double deal.

Versatile Ajax star Jorthy Mokio is the latest midfield option to appear of interest to those at United with the almost certainly more expensive trio of Adam Wharton, Carlos Baleba and Elliot Anderson also wanted.
There is also talk around a possible replacement for the injured Benjamin Sesko. The United striker is set to be out of action for around a month due to injury.
With all of that being said, MEN Sport has you covered with all of the latest transfer talk in our live blog below!
Andre Onana is still hopeful of landing the number one shirt when he returns to Manchester United next summer.
That's according to the i paper, which claims that he believes he can ressurect his career at Old Trafford, despite being sent on loan to Trabzonspor for the season.
The report also adds that Onana is also open to joining another Premier League club to keep his dream of playing in England alive.

After Kobbie Mainoo was struck with an injury prior to Manchester United's clash with Tottenham, there was a danger that the 88-year record of having an academy graduate in the matchday squad could have been lost.
However, Jack Fletcher was given the nod to travel for the match, featuring on the bench for the side in their 2-2 draw with Spurs.
The United youngster is clearly highly rated, as he was spotted in training again today, before the side face off with Everton on Monday.
That was just one of three things spotted in training, and you can read more on today's training session here.
Scott McTominay's success since joining Napoli is well documented, with the former Manchester United midfielder impressing since moving to Italy.
Could that be enough to tempt United into a possible return? Well, TeamTalk claims that the club have sounded out the possibility of a move.
They aren't alone, though, as Arsenal, Tottenham, and Everton have all been linked, too.
It remains to be seen whether such a move could go through in the months ahead.
Journalist David Ornstein has suggested that three of Manchester United's rivals may be in a better position to land Antoine Semenyo this January.
United have been linked with a move for the Bournemouth star, who has a release clause worth £65m, but they could face a challenge in landing him.

Ornstein said on the Athletic FC Podcast: "Let’s see, it wouldn’t surprise you if others came into the mix, but certainly the industry is telling us so far that if there’s to be a move, it’s sounding more like a Liverpool, Man City, Tottenham direction of travel subject to change.”
Ruben Amorim has confirmed Benjamin Sesko is set for a spell on the sidelines after picking up an injury in Manchester United's draw with Tottenham.
"He is going to be a few weeks out," the manager confirmed in his pre-match press conference before facing Everton. "Not that serious we have to be careful. He is feeling better."
Sesko is one of four updates the head coach gave before facing off with the Toffees.
Read more on Man United injury updates.
Manchester United loanee Marcus Rashford is set to miss out on Barcelona's first match at the renovated Nou Camp due to illness.
Hansi Flick confirmed that the forward had picked up a fever in the build-up to the match, with Barcelona welcoming Athletic Club to their new-look stadium tomorrow.
Rashford has scored six times and assisted nine for the club in just 16 appearances, hitting the ground running in La Liga.
Manchester United are set to lose some key stars over the coming weeks, with AFCON getting underway soon, meaning that Bryan Mbeumo, Amad, and Noussair Mazraoui will be in action elsewhere.
There has been some speculation over who could replace those absences, with the January transfer window around the corner, but Ruben Amorim has backed his academy stars to fill the gaps.
Speaking in his pre-match press conference before Everton, he said: "It is a concern but we already knew. There is an opportunity for other players. We have also the under-21s.

"We need to send a message in that time so we will see. But of course it is not ideal because they are so important in our team and we don't have a long squad but again, our academy is for these moments and they will be ready."
Caught Offside sources have claimed that Manchester United are confident they can sign Elliot Anderson for less than Nottingham Forest's current £100m valuation.

They stated: “Financially, the situation is complex. Anderson is under contract with Forest until 2029, giving the club strong leverage. Internally, the club believes Anderson’s value could exceed £100 million if his development continues.
“Still, Manchester United are confident that £60 million would be enough to tempt Forest into negotiations.”
Another continued: “Anderson is open to a move to Old Trafford – he’s drawn by the chance to play on the biggest stage and join one of the big six.”
Dean Holden, Antoine Semenyo's former manager at Bristol City, has stated that he would love to see the Bournemouth star at Manchester United.

He told the Athletic FC Podcast: “We still speak quite a lot, so I’ll certainly be trying to pull him towards a Man United direction, because obviously as a kid, supporting Man United, I would love to see him there.
“I think he’s a player that could play for Man United. I think for Antoine, he has to look where he’s going to go and win trophies.
“Where’s he going to go and win the most trophies? And for me, I’d go and play under Pep Guardiola. If I could go back and put my boots on, I’d be playing under Pep.”
Jean-Philippe Mateta and Crystal Palace have helds talks regarding a contract extension, accoring to The Mirror.
This news comes amid reports linking Manchester United with an interest in the Frenchman.
Ruben Amorim is said to be eyeing a new striker. Mateta currently has 18-months remaining on his contract but could soon sign a new deal.
Manchester United can use the "pure profit" from a Kobbie Mainoo sale to boost their financial position amid a £1bn debt.
Football finance expert Dr Dan Plumley told Football Insider: “I don’t think PSR will be their sole focus. I think it’d be a happy coincidence, if you will.
“We saw this in the summer with PSR and Manchester United. We saw a lot of people were looking at the wrong company. It’s a company called Red Football, which is where the PSR calculation sits.

“So despite the fact that we’ve seen they’ve had, well they’ve told us, they’ve had financial problems and plenty of media reports on that, the outlay that they spent in the summer, people were kind of scratching their heads, but they’re okay with PSR ultimately.

“If this were to go through, I think PSR is probably not the sole driver. Of course, it does benefit Manchester United in that sense as well, because you can book that as pure profit and you can book it in the year that it occurs.“
Sadio Mane has revealed that he was close to joining Manchester United, but former manager Louis Van Gaal did not convince him enough.

He told Rio Ferdinand's YouTube channel: “Van Gaal called me and he said, ‘Mane, how are you? What are you doing?’ He said, ‘I want you to come to Manchester United.’ Okay, now I’m talking to my agent.
“[Van Gaal said], ‘We’ll see what is the best, because I know you’re a good player and you can help the team, and we can help you also to become a better player.
“And then I said, ‘Okay, so my question: you have Depay, you have Rooney, you have Di Maria, you have Van Persie … so where am I going to play?’ That was my question, because me, I want to play.
“He said, ‘I know your talent, you’re good. But if you do good training, good impression, you will play. But we have another player which is also good.’ I was not convinced about his explanation.

“But at the time, me, I was not ready, I can say. I was young. I still needed someone to help me more. And one or two more years to become what I want to be. Because I was still in Southampton, I was not consistent. And then we said, ‘Okay, we’ll see.’”
Former Manchester United midfielder Gordon Strachan believes Andre Onana won't be returing to Old Trafford once his loan-spell in Turkey is over.

He told Esports News: “I think Andre Onana has played his last game for Manchester United. At United you must have a presence in goal – whether it’s physical, attitude, or character, you have to be a presence. I don’t think he had that when he played for the club.

“A big problem for me is that I’m not sure Onana really wanted to be at Old Trafford. He looked like he’d rather be somewhere else and that might be what he needs to start enjoying his football again.
“At no point did I think he was enjoying playing football for United. I’d be shocked if I saw him play again for the club. I think his United career is over in that respect.”
Manchester United centre-back Lisandro Martinez has shown encouraging signs in training after being pictured with Joshua Zirkzee during the November international break.

The Argentine has been out of action since sustaining a serious knee injury in February. However, the 27-year-old has since returned to training at Carrington as he works his way back to full fitness.

Reports suggest that Martinez was granted permission to train with Argentina during the international break to build match fitness. It is currently unclear whether the former Ajax star will be fit enough to be included in United's squad for Monday night's clash against Everton, however...
Read Isaac Seelochan's full story here.
Manchester United will face competition if they are to try and sign Nottingham Forest's Elliot Anderson.

According to The Times, Liverpool and Newcastle United are also interested in the England international. Anderson left Eddie Howe's team in 2024, but the Geordies are seemingly keen on getting him back.
If all these clubs are to fight for Anderson's talents, they will need to meet Forsest's £100m demands.
Carl Anka has revealed further critical details in Antoine Semenyo's release clause that could impact Manchester United's plan to sign the Bournemouth star.

Anka told the Talk of the Devils podcast: “The £65M release clause only works for the first 10 days of the January window. If anybody wants to activate it, Semenyo moves, the money is done quickly and that gives Bournemouth the rest of the window to get a deal done.
“Apparently, there’s a similar apparatus for the summer window as well. There’s some apparatus where the fee can be lowered as well.”
Welcome to the Manchester United transfer blog on Friday November 21.
Premier League football is back this weekend! Ruben Amorim's side will be in action on Monday night against Everton at Old Trafford.
As much as the United boss will be looking ahead to Monday, he will also have an eye on the January transfer window which is now less than 2 months away.
We will keep you up to date with all the latest United transfer news right here - stay tuned.
Former Manchester United striker Dwight Yorke has backed youngster Chido Obi to step up and replace the injured Benjamin Sesko over the next few weeks.
Sesko is set for around a month on the sidelines after suffering a knee injury in the draw against Tottenham before the international break.
Speaking to Snabbare, Yorke said:
"I think Amorim has got to invest in the young players and bring some fresh talent through to give a little bit of a chance if Sesko is out injured.
"If you’re gonna bring in a makeshift option as cover, we’ve seen United do that in the past and it hasn’t worked.
"It’s just too big of a club for bringing in a player that’s not the right fit to improve the team.
"I’d understand if they were flying on all cylinders to get someone else in there but when things are not going so great, it’s a difficult fit.
"If United are going to go and sign someone else, I think they have to go out there like Liverpool and bring in someone who would have a really big presence at the football club.
"Otherwise, the [development side is] there for a reason. What about Chido Obi?
"I know the first team squads are big but you’ve got to get these young players around the team for when situations like this happen.
"When I was at United, the youngsters could train with us and then we’d let them play to get game time and train with us more.
"It’s so that when they come, they are already up to speed. That’s something I would look at."
Manchester United are reportedly one of the clubs monitoring Borussia Dortmund striker Serhou Guirassy ahead of the January transfer window.
According to CaughtOffside, United along with Arsenal and Paris Saint-Germain are all keeping an eye on the striker.
It's added that Guirassy will have a £44 million (€50m) release clause in his contract, but that will only be available to a select group of elite clubs.
The 29-year-old has scored 45 goals in 65 games for Dortmund and is the teammate of reported United target Karim Adeyemi.
Marcus Rashford missed training for Barcelona on Thursday as his team-mates returned from international duty to prepare for Saturday's clash with Athletic Club.

That's despite the Manchester United loanee being at the Ciutat Esportiva a day earlier. According to Diaro AS, Rashford did not attend training on Thursday for "personal reasons" after receiving permission from the La Liga giants, although it is reported that he will regroup with Hansi Flick's squad for preparations on Friday.

The news that Rashford's absence isn't a cause for concern will be welcomed by Barcelona fans. The club are set to return to the fold to face Athletic Club at the Camp Nou on Saturday, with hopes of closing the three-point gap Xabi Alonso's Real Madrid currently hold on them at the peak of the La Liga standings.
Read more here

Patrick Dorgu outlined his grand ambitions for the season when he spoke to Manchester-based correspondents in August, revealing he wanted to win the Premier League and play for Denmark at the 2026 World Cup. The reality is United are a world away from winning the title, but the club staff member who sat in on the interview felt that specific quote reflected Dorgu's ambition and determination.

Unfortunately for Dorgu, his ambition to play at the World Cup next summer may not be realised because Denmark were defeated 4-2 by Scotland at Hampden Park on Tuesday night. If Denmark are to book their place at the tournament they will have to qualify via the play-offs. They played at the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, and Dorgu will be hoping to help his nation reach a third successive tournament.

Dorgu was on the losing side in Scotland, but he notched his third international goal for Denmark when he made it 2-2 with 10 minutes remaining. It was a decent finish in the box, which should give him some much-needed confidence ahead of the return of the Premier League this weekend.
Read the full piece here
Ruben Amorim has admitted that academy players who are "maybe not good enough" to play for Manchester United could be sold to raise funds to work within the Profit and Sustainability Rules (PSR).

Nick Cox helped raise £100million from academy sales during his six-year stint as head of the youth system, but United's director of football Jason Wilcox has identified that as an area where improvement can be made.

Cox joined Everton to become their technical director in September. Former Manchester City academy chief Stephen Torpey was hired from Brentford to succeed Cox, and Torpey has been tasked with increasing revenue from academy sales, while also producing players for the first team at Old Trafford.
Read more here
Manchester United do not meet a traditional big-six side across their next 10 Premier League matches in a huge boost to Ruben Amorim.

The Reds will be feeling much better about themselves after a poor start to the campaign - which had seen head coach Amorim come under increasing pressure. United are currently on a five-match unbeaten run, though, and sit seventh in the top-flight table after 11 games.

Amorim's squad have secured wins over in-form Sunderland, reigning Premier League champions Liverpool and a Brighton side who have caused them major problems in recent seasons. Amorim's men have earned draws in their last two fixtures - at Nottingham Forest and Tottenham Hotspur.
Read more here
Manchester United centre-back Lisandro Martinez has shown encouraging signs in training after being pictured with Joshua Zirkzee during the November international break.

The Argentine has been out of action since sustaining a serious knee injury in February. However, the 27-year-old has since returned to training at Carrington as he works his way back to full fitness.

Reports suggest that Martinez was granted permission to train with Argentina during the international break to build match fitness. It is currently unclear whether the former Ajax star will be fit enough to be included in United's squad for Monday night's clash against Everton, however.
Read more here

Manchester United's summer transfer window went well, but heading towards January the Reds know there is work to be done as their squad still feels light in certain areas. Even with the arrivals of Benjamin Sesko, Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo, the Reds still feel short in attack. Sesko's injury has shown that to be the case.

Should Sesko miss any upcoming games, United seem destined to play Cunha as the false nine with Mbeumo and one of Mason Mount or Amad behind him. But when Mbeumo and Amad leave for AFCON, United suddenly look very short. Ruben Amorim did hint after the Tottenham draw that he could delve into the January market, especially if Sesko's injury is serious.

Even if Sesko doesn't miss a game for United it must be clear to Amorim that another forward addition is needed. Fortunately, the green light has just been given to repeat a trick United used in the summer.

Lisandro Martinez's absence from the Manchester United first team has been painstakingly long. The Argentine suffered an ACL injury against Crystal Palace in February and since then he has missed 35 United matches over 291 days.

Much has changed for United since Martinez left the pitch at Old Trafford on a stretcher against the Eagles. Perhaps most notably, there is optimism that the club have turned a corner under Ruben Amorim. United are on a five-game unbeaten run and are good value for their position just a point outside the top four.

Something else that has changed during Martinez's absence from the first-team squad is Casemiro's role in the team. The Brazilian has become an undroppable for Amorim having previously been written off by some.
However, an impending problem will be concerning the Reds.

Manchester United's chances of signing Borussia Dortmund star Karim Adeyemi have received a significant boost, with reports indicating the forward is actively planning his departure. The German sensation has been on the Reds' radar for some time as they look to enhance their attacking options under Ruben Amorim.

While securing Adeyemi has proven elusive so far, the tide may be about to change with the January transfer window just around the corner - particularly as the 23-year-old appears set on leaving Dortmund. Bild reports that Adeyemi is eager to depart the club at the season's end, with contract renewal talks having hit a deadlock.
However, Dortmund have reportedly slapped a £70 million price tag on him.

Garnacho's future was cast into doubt at the end of last season following his comments about United's season which saw them finish 15th in the Premier League. The Argentine later secured a £40million move to Stamford Bridge, which Chelsea are understood to have offered Lavia as part of the deal for Garnacho at the time..

The club were heavily linked with Brighton's Carlos Baleba, though a move did not materialise due to his £100million price tag. The Daily Mail claims that it was Wilcox, who previously worked at Manchester City and Southampton, Lavia's two clubs before Chelsea, who asked about the 21-year-old's availability. However, United rejected the proposal due to fitness concerns.

Patrick Dorgu outlined his grand ambitions for the season when he spoke to Manchester-based correspondents in August, revealing he wanted to win the Premier League and play for Denmark at the 2026 World Cup. The reality is United are a world away from winning the title, but the club staff member who sat in on the interview felt that specific quote reflected Dorgu's ambition and determination.

Unfortunately for Dorgu, his ambition to play at the World Cup next summer may not be realised because Denmark were defeated 4-2 by Scotland at Hampden Park on Tuesday night. If Denmark are to book their place at the tournament they will have to qualify via the play-offs.

They played at the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, and Dorgu will be hoping to help his nation reach a third successive tournament. Dorgu was on the losing side in Scotland, but he notched his third international goal for Denmark when he made it 2-2 with 10 minutes remaining.
It was a decent finish in the box, which should give him some much-needed confidence ahead of the return of the Premier League this weekend.

Former Arsenal and Manchester City striker Paul Dickov has suggested that Danny Welbeck should think twice before leaving Brighton for a potential return to Manchester United. Welbeck, 34, has been linked with an unexpected move back to Old Trafford following his strong start to the season.

The England international has netted six goals in just 11 top-flight appearances this campaign. He currently stands as the top-scoring Englishman in the Premier League, with Burnley's Jaidon Anthony trailing behind on four and several players, including Arsenal's Bukayo Saka and West Ham's Jarrod Bowen, on three.

Welbeck's impressive form has fuelled rumours that he could be in line for a surprise recall to the England squad for next summer's World Cup, especially given Thomas Tuchel's lack of clear alternatives to Harry Kane. In addition to this, Welbeck has been tipped to make a return to United in the January transfer window, nearly 12 years after he left the Reds to join Arsenal in a £16million deal.

headline: Benjamin Sesko injury update emerges ahead of Man United vs Everton
body: Manchester United striker Benjamin Sesko was not seen taking part in the training session held prior to the clash with Everton on Monday night. The Slovenian hobbled off the pitch against Tottenham Hotspur before the international break, leaving the Reds with just ten men for the remainder of the game.

The forward went straight down the tunnel and Ruben Amorim hinted he may have to delve into the transfer market if his injury is a long-term issue. Whether that is the case or not remains to be seen but Sesko was not seen taking part in training on Friday morning. Harry Maguire and Kobbie Mainoo were also not seen in the training session.

Since Sesko made his full United debut Amorim has either opted to start the Slovenian or play in a strikerless formation, with the latter choice opted for against Liverpool and Tottenham. The Reds could call on Joshua Zirkzee if Sesko is out but so far this season the Dutchman has only played 90 minutes over the course of five appearances.

The more likely option would be for United to stick with the same system which they started with against Spurs. This would mean Amad possibly playing alongside Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha leading the line as a false nine.
Alternatively, Mason Mount could be given a recall to the starting line-up. He impressed when he came on against Tottenham and set up two chances for Sesko in that draw.
Amorim will provide further details on Sesko's injury in his press conference. MEN Sport will bring you updates from his press conference here.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United have an unsung hero who is transforming Old Trafford transfer business
body: In an interview with the United We Stand magazine last year, Sir Jim Ratcliffe slammed the data department at Old Trafford. “Until we are as good as anyone in the world, then it’s not good enough for Manchester United. We must have the best recruitment in the world," said Ratcliffe.

"Data analysis comes alongside recruitment. It doesn’t really exist here. We’re still in the last century on data analysis here. There’s an immense amount of useful data that we can get from data analysis and we’re in the 'very poor' bracket with data analysis here.
"These things don’t happen overnight. You can’t just flick a light switch and sort out recruitment. It’s all about people and we need to find the right people.”
United announced the appointment of Michael Sansoni as director of data in the summer. Ratcliffe discussed the importance of bringing in the "right people" and landed his prime target.

Sansoni was previously the senior performance engineer at the Mercedes F1 team and contributed to eight world championship-winning seasons. United confirmed that Sansoni would be tasked with establishing the club as a data-led organisation, embedding predictive and AI-driven decision-making.
The University of Southampton graduate joined United two months before the official announcement of his appointment, allowing him to be involved in transfers in the summer window.
In July, Sansoni said United had made "meaningful progress" with "new methodologies starting to take shape and two fantastic signings, Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo".

He added: "I’ve inherited a brilliant team: smart, committed, and hungry to make a difference and together we’re building a world-class data and AI function to power decision-making across football and the wider club. The challenge is great, but so is the opportunity. We’re only just getting started."
United's data-led review of 2024/2025 identified the attack as the priority area for strengthening, concluding the shortage of goals was the biggest factor in the team's underperformance.

Benjamin Sesko and Senne Lammens arrived in the second half of the summer transfer window. They were different signings to Cunha and Mbeumo, arriving with no Premier League experience, but the numbers were crunched on both players and United were happy to splash a combined £84.8million.
The press release announcing Sesko's transfer noted that he had scored the most goals of any player under the age of 23 in Europe's top five leagues over the past two seasons.
Jason Wilcox said: "We have followed Benjamin's career closely; all of our data analysis and research concluded that he has the required qualities and personality to thrive at United."

United sources pointed to Lammens' underlying statistics when he signed. They said the Belgium international had one of the highest goals prevented metrics in Europe, with a post-shot expected goals of +14.5, and highlighted he had made more saves than any other goalkeeper in Europe's top 10 leagues.

In layman's terms, post-shot expected goals look at how many goals more or less a goalkeeper has conceded than he's been expected to, based on the quality of shots they have faced. Lammens had essentially prevented 14 goals that an 'average' goalkeeper wouldn't have been able to stop.
"You see the potential of the goalkeeper based on what they do in games; so their positioning, their decision-making and so on, and Senne was always quite high in these areas."
Sesko has scored just two goals since his arrival from RB Leipzig, but Ruben Amorim has backed him to succeed. On the other hand, Lammens has "surprised" Amorim with the extent of his impact.

United's business in the summer window appears to be an improvement on previous years. How much the data is responsible for that is up for debate, but the club's data department, by all accounts, has improved. Sansoni has played a key role and he is currently recruiting staff.
When Sansoni's appointment was communicated, United said further recruitment is planned for a number of data, software and platform engineering roles in the coming months.

Ratcliffe has been ruthless with his club-wide cuts. The employee count has been slashed significantly and every outgoing penny is now scrutinised, but the data department is not shrinking - it's growing.

The United co-owner believes that investing in data can give United an edge, which will theoretically save millions of pounds in the long run. Just think how much has been wasted on transfer fees alone.

United are in the process of hiring a data operations manager to join Sansoni's team to "drive data and technology projects forward". Sansoni has invited hopefuls who are passionate about data to get in touch.
Sansoni is doing important work behind the scenes, impacting United's recruitment.

headline: Sesko, Maguire, Martinez - Man United injury latest and possible return dates vs Everton
body: Manchester United make their return from the November international break when they welcome Everton to Old Trafford in Premier League action.
Ruben Amorim will be keen to get his side back to winning ways, following back-to-back 2-2 draws in the division against Nottingham Forest and Tottenham Hotspur.
United are five unbeaten, however, and have started to click into gear ahead of a reunion with former manager David Moyes.
There are a few injury concerns in the United squad for Amorim to take note of, which could impact his game plan for taking on Everton.
So, with that said, here's a roundup of the latest injury concerns and possible return dates...
Benjamin Sesko is set for a spell on the sidelines after the star striker picked up an injury in the draw with Spurs before the international break.

The Slovenian international struggled with a knee issue and was forced off late in the match, leaving United down to just ten men for the remainder of the game, while he wasn't involved for his nation over the most recent break.

Amorim gave an update on the striker's condition when speaking to the press before the Everton game, and said: "He is going to be a few weeks out. Not that serious we have to be careful. He is feeling better."
It means there could be a return in time for the festive fixture schedule ahead, but he will miss the clash with the Toffees.
Possible return date: December 2025.
After making his way back into the starting line-up last time out, Harry Maguire's afternoon against Tottenham was cut short through a hamstring injury.

The extent of the issue for the defender was unknown, with two weeks to recover over the international break potentially helping him get back towards full fitness, but not in time to face off with Everton.
Amorim simply said: "Maguire is not ready," when asked about the defender's injury.
Possible return date: December 2025.
Kobbie Mainoo missed out on United's trip to Tottenham through a knock he picked up just before the match.
The issue was believed to be minor, meaning he is set to be available again for the clash with Everton at Old Trafford, despite missing out on training on Friday.
On the midfielder, Amorim said: "Kobbie didn't train today but we could see him tomorrow."
Possible return date: Manchester United vs Everton - November 24.
It's been a long road to recovery for Lisandro Martinez, who picked up an ACL injury back in February, but the defender is nearing a full return.
The Argentinian international returned to full training just before the international break, though Amorim decided against throwing him straight back into action.
While he wasn't called up to the squad, Martinez did join up with his Argentina teammates to train, in preparation for his return to action.
On the possibility of him featuring against Everton, Amorim said: "Licha is getting close to be playing."
Possible return date: Manchester United vs Everton - November 24.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United give Old Trafford update in time for Premier League return
body: Manchester United have confirmed they will officially open one of the largest safe standing sections in the Premier League when Everton make the trip to Old Trafford on Monday night.

United installed 6,000 additional rail seats in the second tier of the Stretford End in September. The work has now been completed and certified by the Sports Grounds Safety Authority for safe standing.
The addition of the new section adds to existing safe standing areas in all four quadrants of the stadium, while it brings the number of rail seats to 13,577, 18 per cent of total capacity.
The official capacity of Old Trafford following the latest installation of safe standing is 74,412.
United said: "Safe standing is recognised to improve fan safety while also enhancing atmosphere in areas of the ground where fans prefer to stand.

"The club has been gradually expanding safe standing since the first rail seats were installed in the north-east quadrant in 2021, with support from fan representatives and the Manchester United Supporters’ Trust.
"Fans with season tickets in the second tier of the Stretford End were surveyed before work began and this demonstrated strong support for safe standing in the section."
United have worked with fans to improve the atmosphere at Old Trafford, opening lines of dialogue with supporters to permit dozens of flags and banners to be unfurled in the Stretford End.

In August, the club sent an email to season ticket holders about their preferences for music around the game. United wanted to know if ‘Glory Glory Man United’ should be played immediately after a win.
More than 50 per cent wanted the song to be played no matter what, while 24 per cent said they’d prefer no music after a defeat. The decision was made only to play 'Glory Glory' after a win.

United began to play 'Take Me Home, Country Roads' by John Denver shortly before kick-off at Old Trafford at the beginning of last season. The track was released in 1971 and has been an anthem for fans for decades, but the decision to play it directly before kick-off has helped atmosphere.
United will return from the international break when they welcome Everton to Manchester on Monday. Ruben Amorim's side will be looking to extend their unbeaten run to six games.

headline: Antoine Semenyo has told Man United exactly what they needed amid £65m clause
body: Just for once, Manchester United couldn't be criticised too much for how the summer transfer window played out. Considering the lack of Champions League football this season, it always seemed like it would be difficult to attract players to the club and, yet, they managed to address the major concerns.

Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Benjamin Sesko were brought in to bolster an attack which stuttered badly last season. Senne Lammens was signed to improve the goalkeeping ranks and he has managed to do that well. The only area of the pitch seemingly neglected was midfield, but it was agreed that was further down the priority list at that juncture.

It's only as the season has progressed though that United's attack has shown signs of needing further investment. Many assumed Joshua Zirkzee would have more involvement than he has considering Rasmus Hojlund left, but he does not seem to be trusted by Ruben Amorim.

It has left United with a lack of options in the centre-forward role. Sesko is the only out-and-out No.9 in the first-team squad, but he is still adapting to the Premier League. Chido Obi is an option but, at 17, his short-term career plan is best served in the academy set-up.

When Amorim wants to bring in a replacement for Sesko, the Reds currently have to adopt a striker-less system - which has worked against the likes of Liverpool - but isn't necessarily ideal for matches where a focal point up top is needed. That is why the availability of Antoine Semenyo should be appealing to the recruitment department.
Semenyo fits the same mould as Mbeumo and Cunha. He's a player who has proven he can do it in the Premier League and has a goal-scoring record to match that.

In a recent interview with Jason Wilcox, the United sporting director explained how the club made a decision to sign players in attack who they could 'plug in and play' in the Premier League. This does not mean signing players who solely fit the system, but also ones who know the division and can settle immediately.

Were they to sign Semenyo, then he would be another player who could do just that. Another similarity between Mbeumo and the Bournemouth attacker is the concerns surrounding whether he can feature as a No.10, or centre-forward, considering he plays as a right winger for his club.
However, speaking back in January, the Ghana international told the Reds exactly what they wanted to hear. "I feel like I'm comfortable playing in any role across the forward positions," he said.
"This comes with the ability to use both feet, I think. I'm comfortable playing whether on the left, right or in the middle.
"However, in my head the end goal is to be a No.9. Maybe in the years to come when I've built the experience I'll eventually transition into that, but I'm not too hung up on that."
If United are to spend a vast amount of money on a player, they need to know he can feature in a role suitable for Amorim's system. With those comments, Semenyo has offered reassurances that he can.

It will be a huge surprise if Semenyo is still at Bournemouth by the end of the January transfer window. If he stays injury free, and continues the sort of form he has been showing so far, there will be Premier League clubs queuing up for him.

Semenyo is understood to have a £65million release clause which will be active in the early stages of the January window. It's said it will expire shortly after the window opens to allow Bournemouth time to sign a replacement if necessary.

As such, we can expect any potential suitors to swarm on him as soon as the window begins and United need to be ready for that. If Semenyo now proves to be a serious target for the Reds in the transfer market, Zirkzee will undoubtedly need to leave and we understand a request from the Dutchman is likely to be lodged in January if his game time doesn't increase.
Should that happen, it's a no brainer for United. They must look to rake in as much as they can for Zirkzee and then use that money to attempt to sign Semenyo.
He has told the Reds exactly what they needed to hear so now is the time to start planning their approach.

headline: Major update issued in Old Trafford regeneration plans
body: A major new update in the regeneration plans for the area around Manchester United's Old Trafford football stadium has been announced.

Lord Sebastian Coe, who won four Olympic medals and headed the successful bid for the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games, has already been named as chair designate of the Old Trafford Regeneration Mayoral Development Corporation (MDC), which will help drive forward the huge project.
Karen Hirst has now been named as Project Director, working alongside Lord Coe. The chartered surveyor will lead delivery for the corporation.

The establishment of the MDC has been approved by Trafford Council and Greater Manchester Combined Authority, following a recommendation by Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham. It will be legally formalised following Parliamentary approval.
Most recently, Ms Hirst was managing director of Maple Grove Developments, overseeing major commercial projects in the North West, including industrial, logistics and town centre regeneration.

She has also been a group board director of Eric Wright Group, and development director at both Salford City Council and Central Salford Regeneration Company, during her 35 years in property and development. Karen is also a non-executive director of Regenda Group.

The MDC will co-ordinate multi-million-pound efforts to transform the area, as a key part of the Greater Manchester Strategy. Forthcoming housing development in Old Trafford has already been allocated a significant share of the newly-announced £1bn Good Growth Fund.

The MDC is set to attract public and private sector investment to accelerate transformational regeneration, creating a world-class, sports-led visitor destination, rich in culture and entertainment. Ambitions are 'to make Old Trafford one of the best places in the UK to live, work, and visit', with up to 15,000 new homes, including affordable homes, as well as employment opportunities.
Hirst will be responsible for delivering the strategic vision for the Old Trafford regeneration, developing and implementing a business plan to make it happen.

"I am excited to be taking on this new role and I am looking forward to working with Lord Coe, the teams at GMCA, Trafford Council, Manchester United FC and other key partners, stakeholders and local residents," she said.

"After working in both the private and public sector, I know that ambitious regeneration projects such as Old Trafford regeneration are challenging and will require many parties and people to make it a success."
Lord Coe, meanwhile, praised her 'wealth of experience coupled with her passion and enthusiasm'.

In March, United unveiled ambitious plans for a state-of-the-art 100,000-seater stadium, Now, an initial commitment of £26m for 382 new homes as part of the Trafford Wharf development has been promised – the first major investment in the Old Trafford regeneration area.

headline: Manchester United vs Man City derby date confirmed as both clubs see fixtures moved
body: The second Manchester derby of the season will take place on Saturday, January 17 at 12.30pm after the Premier League confirmed the latest fixtures to be moved for TV coverage.

The Blues won the first derby of the season 3-0 at the Etihad, with Erling Haaland scoring twice after Phil Foden had got the ball rolling. That mid-September clash got City back on track after a shaky start to the season, but United have also improved under Ruben Amorim and they will expect to put up a better fight at Old Trafford.

The last time a league fixture between the clubs was staged on a Saturday lunchtime came in January 2023, when United won 2-1. Jack Grealish gave City the lead before the hosts turned the game around in the final 12 minutes. Bruno Fernandes scored a controversial equaliser and Marcus Rashford bagged the winner.

headline: Man United know the one thing they can't do in Marcus Rashford transfer plan
body: Manchester United will find it difficult not to look on enviously at Barcelona this season considering how well Marcus Rashford has done for them.
The loan spell to Catalonia was the last throw of the dice for Rashford. His bridges were burnt with Ruben Amorim and, for all involved, the best thing to do was to let him leave.
Rashford wanted Barca in January but an approach was not deemed viable by the La Liga giants. Fortunately for the United academy graduate, they returned in the summer and the deal was done.

He joined the Camp Nou club on a season-long loan with the option to purchase him in the summer. If all goes according to plan for United, Rashford will impress, Barca will trigger that option and the winger's time in Spain continues.

Six goals and nine assists in 16 appearances suggests Barca will want to keep Rashford. Whether they have the finances to do it is another issue. Barca can sign the England international for £28m in the summer but the financial pressures Barcelona face are well documented.
No matter how well Rashford does at Barca or for England, he will not have a place to come back to at Old Trafford. Amorim has made his mind up and therefore the task would be to find him a new club.
Kitbag has slashed the price of Man United kits and merch with up to 50% off select items.

With that in mind, United know what they can't do. Sell Rashford to a Premier League rival. In Spain, El Nacional has reported that Chelsea and Tottenham Hotspur have both made early contact with Rashford's agent to try and persuade him to move to the Premier League. United can't let that happen.

If he was to impress in the Premier League, suddenly Rashford becomes a more prominent issue for the United head coach. So ideally United must find a way of making things work with Barca. The alternative of him returning to England with Chelsea or Spurs is not worth thinking about.
United can only hope that if it comes to it, Rashford still does not fancy a move down to London...

headline: RAILSTON: How Manchester United's 18 loanees are doing this season - Rashford, Onana and Collyer
body: Manchester United sent plenty of players out on loan in the summer transfer window.
Marcus Rashford and Andre Onana were among the highest-profile loan exits from the club, while Rasmus Hojlund and Jadon Sancho completed moves to Napoli and Aston Villa respectively.

There were several players from the academy sent on loan to gain experience. Some of those youngsters are excelling, while others have not made the impact they might have hoped. United loaned 18 players in total - and here is how they are faring this season.

Sheffield Wednesday have been hit with a 12-point deduction due to their ownership situation, but they were able to promise regular game time to Amass, who has made 11 starts. The youngster scored his first senior goal against Southampton and United are delighted with his stint so far.

Collyer was limited to seven substitute appearances after his arrival. He broke into the starting team against Millwall last month and retained his role in the next game, but he picked up a muscle injury.

Ennis spent the second half of last season with promotion-winning Doncaster Rovers. The youngster joined Fleetwood on a season-long deal for this campaign and he has started eight league games. Has contributed two goals and an assist during his positive loan spell in League Two.

Gore picked up an injury shortly after signing for Rotherham last January, but he made a strong impression in the time he was available, so he was re-signed for this season. Gore has been crucial for Rotherham in midfield. Has started in 15 games in League One and has been one of their best players.

Onana has received praise in the Turkish media since his move to Trabzonspor, who have lost just once in the league from a possible eight games since he signed. The 29-year-old has recorded three clean sheets and helped Trabzonspor to third in the table.

After missing the opening two games of the League Two campaign due to a minor injury, Harrison started the next four games for Shrewsbury Town before reporting for England Under-20 duty in September. In his absence, another young goalkeeper came into the side and has earned first-choice status over Harrison.
Hugill started the first two games of the season for Barnet in League Two, but he picked up an injury and has been absent since.

Defender Aljofree started the first eight games of the campaign and notched a goal but he has lost his starting role over the last few weeks. The 20-year-old was not in the squad for Notts County played Harrogate Town last weekend.

Solihull Moors are midtable in the National League. Jackson started in their first two games of the season, but he has struggled to make the XI since. The centre-back has been absent from their last five matchday squads.

Hojlund made an excellent first impression in Naples, scoring twice against Sporting Lisbon in the Champions League shortly after his arrival, but he has scored just four goals in total. Hojlund has copped some flak from the Italian media for his recent performances. Napoli won Serie A last season but sit fourth.
Kana-Biyik recently scored his first senior goal. He salvaged a point for Lausanne in a local derby and was called up to France's Under-20 squad for the November international break.
Moorhouse has made 15 appearances for League One side Leyton Orient, but just four of those have been league starts. The youngster has shown glimpses of quality from the bench.

Dave Hughes, who coached Ogunneye in United's academy, has just departed Newport County. That might impact Ogunneye's role in the squad, but the youngster has made 13 league starts in League Two so far and gained valuable experience, albeit in a struggling dressing room.

Barcelona seemed a great fit for Rashford to rediscover his form. The United academy graduate has contributed six goals and nine assists in 16 appearances this season, and has looked back to his best.

Rashford has been revitalised by leaving on loan - but Sancho continues to be in a slump. The winger has not started for Aston Villa in the Premier League and has failed to record a goal or an assist.

Vitek has started every league game for Bristol City in the Championship, keeping five clean sheets. The 22-year-old has made some great saves. Bristol City manager Gerhard Struber recently said of Vitek to the Bristol Post: “He’s young, and he looks like an outstanding, experienced Championship goalkeeper.”

Wheatley needed to leave on loan after outgrowing academy football. The young striker has made 13 starts in League Two for Northampton and has found the back of the net twice, as well as recording two assists.

Williams is performing well north of the border. Has contributed a goal and three assists in nine appearances in the Scottish top-flight for Falkirk, who are exceeding expectations by sitting fifth in the table.

headline: Man United manager didn't respect me so I had to leave - now I'm on the brink of World Cup history
body: Zidane Iqbal is used to making history.

The midfielder became the first British-born South Asian to represent Manchester United and the first to play in the Champions League. Iqbal came off the bench against Young Boys in December 2021 and at that stage in his career it looked only a matter of time until he was handed more regular opportunities.

Chances may not have materialised at Old Trafford but Iqbal and his Iraq team-mates have a significant one tonight. A win against the United Arab Emirates in the home leg of their World Cup qualifying play-off will keep alive the dream of qualifying for the tournament next summer.

Iqbal, who was the first Iraqi to play for United, came off the bench in last week's first leg, which ended 1-1 and leaves Iraq as marginal favourites to progress. Should they prevail they will enter a six team inter-continental play-off in March. Their world ranking is likely to see them go straight into one of the two finals and thus one win away from the World Cup.

For Iraq that would be a first appearance since their sole qualification in 1986. For Iqbal it would be the latest piece of history and perhaps vindication for opting to leave United and move to Utrecht in the Netherlands.
The tipping point for the now 22-year-old was a lack of opportunities and a seeming lack of trust from then manager Erik ten Hag in granting him a first team chance during the 2022-23 campaign.

"I thought I would get a chance and unfortunately I didn’t," said Iqbal in an interview last summer. "I just wanted 10 minutes off a bench to show myself and it really frustrated me that the gaffer didn’t seem to rate me enough to give me a chance to show if I could sink or swim.

"I spoke to my dad and agent and said: 'I can't do this for another year'. From the outside, it looked amazing to all my friends because I was training and travelling with United’s first team. For me, it was mentally tough because I was just training and not allowed to play with the Under-23s. I thought to myself, 'I'm just like a number'.

"I was supposed to start a cup game against Charlton. I was in all the shapes and patterns in pre-match training. I was starting as a 10 and Lisandro Martinez came up to me and said: 'Now's your chance'. He talked to me and said, 'all of us are supporting you. Just show yourself, you're a good player. We're going to fight for you, make sure you're ready to fight'. It motivated me and it was nice from him, an aggressive leader in the team, a big player. I got tickets for family and friends to see me. Finally, my chance.

"Then I got to the stadium, looked at the whiteboard and didn't see my name. I was gutted. Then I thought I'd come off the bench. Nothing. That was the turning point for me. I didn't feel the manager respected me enough to play me."

Iqbal turned down the chance to play at the Under-19 World Cup in April 2023 after Ten Hag told him he wanted to retain him as part of the United senior squad, but no club minutes followed and that summer he left for the Netherlands for a fee in the region of £1million.

Injury has hampered his opportunity for regular minutes in Holland but he is closing in on 50 senior opportunities for the club and is a regular for the national team, scoring a crucial goal in a victory over Indonesia earlier this season. He'd love another against the UAE this afternoon (4pm), it would be the latest chapter of a history-making career.

headline: Man United star Mason Mount reaches out to family after horror crash and critical injury
body: Mason Mount has shown support for the family of a big Manchester United fan in Bolton who continues to fight for his life after being struck by a car. Mount has sent a video message to Lewis Rimmer's wife, Sarah, and two daughters, Amelia and Maddison, in the aftermath of a Range Rover hitting him and causing 'life-changing' injuries.

He remains 'critically ill' in hospital after being put in an induced coma, his close friend Andy Tonge has told the MEN. Tonge described the message as 'lovely' for the family. The Bolton News quotes him as saying: "They're big Manchester United supporters, so this was lovely to receive, what a guy."

Mount is said to have shared his condolences and expressed his sorrow at hearing what happened to Rimmer. He also relayed that "everyone at Manchester United is thinking of them and sending all their love." A fundraiser set up by friends to raise money for the family has received over £100,000 in donations.

Tonge has said: "The incident seems to have really struck a chord with people. It happened during half term, and it’s shocked so many because it could so easily have been a child who might not have been as strong as Lewis is proving to be.
"Many feel that Lewis’ strength and fight over the last few weeks is nothing short of remarkable.
"The fact that it took place at a local supermarket, used by so many of us, has created an even stronger sense of, 'This could have happened to anyone of us.'"

Tonge added: "Lewis, unfortunately, is still critically ill and remains in an induced coma, three weeks on. Sarah and the family have been by his side every single day, and the fundraiser has genuinely lifted them.
"Knowing that so many people care and want to support them has made a real difference.
"When the time comes to make necessary changes to their home and daily life, they’ll be able to focus on Lewis without the added pressure of financial worries."
And, finally, if you would rather listen to our expert analysis, then make sure to check out our Manchester is Red podcast.
Sky will show at least 215 live Premier League games this season, an increase of up to 100 more.

headline: Two Manchester United players have what it takes to recover from setbacks
body: Modern football is often a reflection of the world surrounding it.

When the older generations were watching the sport in the 1960s and 1970s, discussions surrounding the mental stability of a player or the squad was rarely aired. However, as the world became more aware of the challenges of mental health, football has accepted it and now each Premier League club takes into account the psychological fortitude of a player during every aspect of their career - all the way from scouting to the day they depart.
Manchester United are no exception and within their current squad there are two players who are facing mental challenges which shall be putting them to the test. First, is Lisandro Martinez.

Little more than a year after suffering a severe foot injury, the Argentine damaged his ACL and has been sidelined since February. He is now back with the United camp as he continues his recovery and his return to the pitch is expected before the festive period.

But managing to navigate past the mental barrier of returning to professional football will be the crucial step in Martinez's recovery. Specialist in psychology at Manchester Metropolitan University Dr Martin Turner, who has worked with The FA and Scarlets Rugby, believes the 27-year-old could come back a stronger athlete.
"I imagine he [Martinez] will be worrying that it [his injury] would happen again," Dr Turner told MEN Sport. "That is just sensible. That is just the reality.

"What you wouldn’t want a player like that to do is delude themselves that this will never happen again and everything is always going to be hunky-dory because sport is so unpredictable, and there is so much uncertainty that you can never really predict what is going to happen.

"But having gone through two quite difficult injuries, he will have learnt quite a lot and his personality and character would have had some shifts. From my experience of working with athletes who have especially had these back-to-back injuries and even sometimes surgeries, they do develop a shift in their personality.

"I wouldn’t say it is necessarily more resilience, but there is clarity there of what this means to them. They suddenly have a gratitude and thinking of: ‘Well, this could go away at any minute, so I am going to apply myself doubly compared to what I was doing before. I am going to really take care of this and do all the right things.'"

"You can’t put it to one side and say that is done now because there will be monitoring that takes place after training and after performances around that injury and around recovery to make sure that everything is going well.
"There will be physical limitations because it will have been a long time since they have played to the intensity of a proper game.

"So it is not just a case of putting it to the back of your mind but about trusting the medical professionals you are working with to know that they would not let you step on this pitch, if you wasn’t physically right. Players have to take confidence from that and trust the people they are working with and then they can trust their bodies."

Martinez's teammate Bryan Mbeumo is currently negotiating a different type of mental challenge heading out of the international break. Last week, Cameroon lost to DR Congo in World Cup qualifying meaning Mbeumo's national team will not be competing in the USA, Mexico and Canada next summer.

Missing out on the World Cup, arguably the pinnacle of football, will have been a bitter blow for Mbeumo to take but Dr Turner believes that United do not have to fear the forward's confidence dropping upon his return to England.

"I am not sure they would have to do, or do anything special there," he explained. "Experienced players are able to lift themselves, really, and move on quite quickly. One of the good things about football in particular is how quickly things move from game-to-game.

"Say you play badly and then you play well in the next game, it is sort of completely forgotten. Things move on so quickly so he would be expected to come back and hit the ground running and get his club mentality on.

"I think the direction of football, particularly in this country, is more of a club mentality and it is realised that is your bread and butter. I wouldn’t foresee any issues there and I wouldn’t expect staff to do anything in particular for that player.
"I might be wrong and I have no idea what is going on behind the scenes, but from my experience of being in environments like that, it would be an expectation to get back on your feet and go again.

"The more that you make a big deal of something that has happened or bring it into the room, the more that is going to affect other players so you have got to get him back moving, playing and within the mentality of the squad."

headline: Why phone call with Man United star can give Ruben Amorim boost he needs
body: Earlier this month, Manchester United fans were left scratching their heads as one of their best players this season was snubbed again.

Luke Shaw endured a tough start to the season, following on from a campaign ruined by injuries. The 2024/25 season did not go according to plan for anyone in red, but Shaw in particular was being doubted after another season spent mainly on the sidelines.
However, full credit must go to Shaw for the manner in which he has bounced back.

Following the disaster at Manchester City, Shaw has been dependable for the Reds this campaign in a back three. He had to deal with plenty of criticism following that derby day defeat - notably from Roy Keane - and after addressing it, he set about making amends.

Ever since that game, Shaw has got better and better for United and you can see him settling into his new role on the left side of defence. That's why it was surprising when England head coach Thomas Tuchel overlooked him for the final World Cup qualifiers this month.

While being overlooked for selection will have been a blow to Shaw, Ruben Amorim will have taken the positives from the decision. He admitted himself, from a selfish perspective, he wanted all his players to be training and recovering at United during the international break. But he would still be delighted to see Shaw competing with England.

"For me, I want him to go to the national team, but I also want Luke Shaw to train with me, recover with me, and be prepared for my game, so I'm a little bit selfish on that, so if he's not going to the national team, for me it's fine, because I can control better what he's doing," Amorim said earlier this season.

While missing out on the November camp was a big blow for Shaw, Tuchel has admitted it is not necessarily the end of his World Cup dream. "First of all, it's my job now to make contact with everyone," the England head coach said at the end of the Three Lions' final international break this year.

"Players like Trent [Alexander-Arnold], players that are on our long list, 55, 60 players, to reach out to them, be in touch with them, explain to them why they were not here. Explain to them what they have to do, where they can improve.
"Can they even do something or is it just a choice, so this is my job in the next weeks and months."
Shaw and Harry Maguire will be on Tuchel's list of 55-60 players who he is in contact with to discuss their spots in the England squad.
That phone call should work to United's benefit. Shaw will know exactly what he needs to do over the next few months to put himself in contention and that can only help United.
Shaw will be eager to show Tuchel that he was wrong to overlook him. The best way to do that will be to impress for Amorim and the Reds.

headline: Matthijs de Ligt makes true feelings on biggest Ruben Amorim criticism at Man United clear
body: Manchester United centre-back Matthijs de Ligt has admitted he is finding the five-at-the-back system under Ruben Amorim easier as time progresses.

Amorim has been heavily criticised for his decision to stick with the five-at-the-back defence, with three centre-backs playing alongside two wing-backs. Some argued the Portuguese head coach needed to be pragmatic and revert to a traditional four-at-the-back system in order to secure results.

Prior to the Burnley victory and with scrutiny mounting, the United boss told reporters: "Guys, if I feel that it's best to change... I played all my life in the 4-4-2, 4-3-3. The only system that I didn't play one minute: 3-4-3.

"I just have one idea that we need to be so good in this way of playing, then we are going to adapt. It's like some coaches have a mentality that I'm going to put this system, and then I'm going to change.
"What I'm thinking is that we have one system that is going to adapt to different systems, and then when everyone is doing this with his eyes shut, I'm going to change a lot of things."
United are on a five-game unbeaten run and sit a point outside the top four. Integral to this recent form has been De Ligt, who has started every Premier League match for Amorim this season.

On Monday night, he played the full 90 minutes alongside Liverpool's Virgil van Dijk in a back four as the Netherlands beat Lithuania in their final World Cup qualifier to top their group. After the game, De Ligt was quizzed on his preference and the 26-year-old insisted that he does not have one.
"No, I don't really have a preference," he told Flashscore. "We play with a five-man defence at Manchester United, but on paper, we defend with four.
"It didn't feel awkward today; it felt the same as always. I can play in both systems. I'm more experienced with a five-man defence now; the more experience you have, the easier it gets."
In the last match before the November international break, you could see De Ligt's point in practice. United would often drop to a back four with Luke Shaw moving into central midfield.

The Netherlands have now qualified for the World Cup and De Ligt expressed his delight post-match to have made his first start for his country since last November. "Whether it's a comeback? Yeah, a bit," he admitted.
"I wasn't here last time, I haven't started for a long time, so I'm delighted with today. The season is going well so far.
"I'm not sure if you call it a comeback season, but I'm feeling well, and it's going better with the club, and now I'm rewarded with a start, so that's great."
"It's [the World Cup] still far away," De Ligt added. "It'll be about being fit a lot, that's the most important thing to everyone."
